item.value: Mount Everest is the tallest mountain in the world. It is 8850 meters (29035ft) high.
Intel introduces the first microprocessor, the Intel 4004 on November 15, 1971.
The shortest woman was Pauline Muster. She was 58 cm ( 23 in ) tall.
The 1921 Nobel Prize in Physics was won by Albert Einstein for his work in the field of theoretical physics.
The moon is just over one quarter the size of the earth.
In 1972 Ray Tomlinson at BBN developed the first e-mail program. In his first email to himself, he uses the @ sign. This was the first time it appeared in an e-mail address.
The tallest woman was Zeng Jinlian. She was 2.48 meters ( 8ft 2in ) tall.
The closest planet to earth is Venus. It is about 38 million kilometers away. It would take over 4 years to travel there by plane.
More than 1,000 different languages are spoken on the continent of Africa.
The Cambodian alphabet is the world's largest alphabet, with 74 letters. The world's shortest alphabet, used in the Solomon Islands, has only 11.
On average, Elephants sleep for about 2 hours per day.
John Logie Baird was the inventor of the world's first working television system in Hastings, England in 1923.
By 2008 there were almost 1.3 billion telephone lines in the world.
The blue whale is the largest known animal on Earth. The second largest animal is the Afican elephant.
A shark can hear a fish in the water from more than a mile away.
The longest word in a major English dictionary is 'Pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis'. It is 45 characters long.
Opened in 2010, the Burj Khalifa in Dubai is the tallest building in the world.
The Sun is one of about 200 billion stars in the Milky Way galaxy. The most current estimates guess that there are 100 to 200 billion galaxies in the Universe
English is the second most spoken language in the world.
Light travels slower through different substances such as glass, water and air.
